content: Public and private health care spending is increasing due to factors like rising health insurance enrollment and an aging population. The tax subsidies in the Internal Revenue Code for health care provision are often overlooked in budget discussions, as they result in revenue foregone through preferential tax treatment. Congressional focus on health-related tax expenditures is important. Implicit subsidies in the Internal Revenue Code for private and publicly provided health care, in the form of tax expenditures, are often overlooked in public debates. Congressional attention to health-related tax expenditures is crucial, raising questions about their value and changes over time, especially since the enactment of the Affordable Care Act. Tax expenditures related to health are often overlooked in public debates. Questions arise about their value, changes over time, and comparison to total revenue collected. The size of health tax expenditures relative to discretionary and mandatory health program outlays is also of interest. Additionally, the growth of federal support for health through direct outlays versus revenue losses from tax expenditures is a topic for consideration. This report analyzes historical data on health-related tax expenditure estimates published by the Joint Committee on Taxation (JCT) to understand changes in tax expenditures relative to total revenue collected and the size of health tax expenditures compared to discretionary and mandatory health program outlays. It also examines whether federal support for health has grown more through direct outlays or indirectly through revenue losses attributable to tax expenditures.
